coredata.dc:title: Operando diffuse reflectance infrared detection of cyanide intermediate species during the reaction of formaldehyde with ammonia over V2O5/WO3-TiO2

coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen cyanide (HCN) is a highly poisonous gas that can form through the reaction between formaldehyde and ammonia (NH3) in the exhaust. While this detrimental side reaction has been the subject of recent catalytic studies under selective catalytic reduction conditions, the molecular mechanism leading to the release of HCN remains far from elucidated. Here, we report the detection of the cyanide intermediate species by operando diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy, thereby providing unambiguous evidence that the HCN-forming reaction occurs on the catalyst surface. Formaldehyde likely reacts from the gas phase with pre-adsorbed NH3 to form HCN. Although formate species were formed abundantly upon formaldehyde introduction, they were not responsible for the high level of HCN emissions observed. TiO2 alone is sufficient to catalyze the side reaction, but VOx and/or WOx sites increase HCN production by preventing the formation of inactive polyamide species. These mechanistic insights should serve as a basis for understanding the chemistry responsible for the side reaction so that mitigation measures can be put forward.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: DRIFT spectra of V2O5/WO3-TiO2 during formaldehyde adsorption under oxidative conditions at 300 °C. Experimental conditions: 150 ppm HCHO and 5 vol% O2 in Ar.

DRIFT spectra of V2O5/WO3-TiO2 after 30 min of (a) formaldehyde and NH3 reaction; (b) NH3 adsorption; and (c) formaldehyde adsorption at 300 °C. Experimental conditions: 150 ppm formaldehyde, 1000 ppm NH3, and 5 vol% O2 in Ar.

DRIFT spectra of (a) V2O5/WO3-TiO2 and (b) TiO2 after 30 min of formaldehyde + NH3 reaction (HCHO on, NH3 on), NH3 exposure (HCHO off, NH3 on), and treatment under O2 (HCHO off, NH3 off) at 300 °C. Experimental conditions: 150 ppm formaldehyde, 1000 ppm NH3, and 5 vol% O2 in Ar.

Temporal evolution of the area of the ν(C≡N) mode as well as the signals of HCN (m/z = 27) and formaldehyde (m/z = 29) upon NH3 addition. Experimental conditions: 150 ppm formaldehyde, 1000 ppm NH3, and 5 vol% O2 in Ar.

= 300 °) of a similar experiment with 2 vol% H2O. The selected phase angles correspond to the spectra where the signal of the peak at 1731 cm−1 was maximum. The full sets of phase-resolved spectra of the water-free and water-containing experiments are shown in Fig. S-4 and Fig. S-5, respectively.

Temporal evolution of the normalized signals of cyanide (2196 cm−1), formaldehyde (1731 cm−1), and amide (1686 cm−1) species during alternate exposures to a gas feed containing: (a) formaldehyde/NH3 and NH3; and (b) formaldehyde/NH3 and formaldehyde at 300 °C. The signal of formaldehyde (1701 cm−1) in a NH3-free cut-off experiment is also presented in (a) for comparison. Experimental conditions: 150 ppm formaldehyde, 1000 ppm NH3, and 5 vol% O2 in Ar.

DRIFT spectra of V2O5/WO3-TiO2 after 30 min of (a) formic acid + NH3 reaction; (b) NH3 adsorption; and (c) formic acid adsorption at 300 °C. Experimental conditions: 150 ppm formaldehyde, 1000 ppm NH3, and 5 vol% O2 in Ar.

Contour plots of the ν(C≡N) region upon NH3 addition to V2O5/WO3-TiO2 pre-equilibrated with (a) formaldehyde and (b) formic acid feeds. Conditions: 150 ppm formaldehyde (or 150 ppm formic acid), 1000 ppm NH3, and 5 vol% O2 in Ar,.
DRIFT spectra of (a) TiO2 and (b) V2O5/WO3-TiO2 after formaldehyde and NH3 reaction at 300 °C. Experimental conditions: 150 ppm formaldehyde, 1000 ppm NH3 and 5 vol% O2 in Ar.

head.ce:title: Operando diffuse reflectance infrared detection of cyanide intermediate species during the reaction of formaldehyde with ammonia over V2O5/WO3-TiO2

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Hydrogen cyanide (HCN) is a highly poisonous gas that can form through the reaction between formaldehyde and ammonia (NH3) in the exhaust. While this detrimental side reaction has been the subject of recent catalytic studies under selective catalytic reduction conditions, the molecular mechanism leading to the release of HCN remains far from elucidated. Here, we report the detection of the cyanide intermediate species by operando diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy, thereby providing unambiguous evidence that the HCN-forming reaction occurs on the catalyst surface. Formaldehyde likely reacts from the gas phase with pre-adsorbed NH3 to form HCN. Although formate species were formed abundantly upon formaldehyde introduction, they were not responsible for the high level of HCN emissions observed. TiO2 alone is sufficient to catalyze the side reaction, but VOx and/or WOx sites increase HCN production by preventing the formation of inactive polyamide species. These mechanistic insights should serve as a basis for understanding the chemistry responsible for the side reaction so that mitigation measures can be put forward.

ce:section.ce:para: Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) is currently the most efficient means of nitrogen oxide (NOx) removal in lean-burn engines. The word “selective” is imposed on the term because the introduced reactant – a reducing agent – should react specifically with NOx molecules, and not with the large excess of oxygen in the exhaust gas [1]. Although modern catalyst formulations and process design considerations have greatly hampered the occurrence of side reactions during SCR, some of them can still occur in parallel. One of the most undesired ones is the formation of hydrogen cyanide (HCN), a potent toxic gas that can negatively impact human health and the environment [2,3].

The formation of HCN under SCR conditions was first documented in the case of hydrocarbon-SCR over Cu-ZSM-5 [4–7]. The type of hydrocarbon strongly affected the production of HCN, and the presence of water in the feed generally promoted the reaction [7]. It became evident that HCN formation was actually an intermediate step in the NOx reduction mechanism and not a competing side reaction, which is congruent with the decrease of the HCN concentration as the hydrocarbon-SCR activity increases at higher temperatures [6,7]. Adsorbed NOx molecules were proposed to react with the hydrocarbon from the gas phase to form an organic nitro compound, which then transforms into HCN, cyanogen (C2N2), or isocyanic acid (HNCO) before eventually being reduced into nitrogen gas (N2) [8,9]. In the case of Fe-ZSM-5, the production of HCN even exceeded that of the desired N2 product below 300 °C, demonstrating that the hydrocarbon-SCR cycle is significantly halted in the low-temperature regime [10]. Addition of water increased the level of HCN production and SCR activity in general up to 275 °C, which was attributed to the ability of water to suppress the formation of carbonaceous residues. Above this temperature, the presence of water limited HCN production in conjunction with enhanced N2 formation. This apparent promotion of NOx conversion was attributed to HCN hydrolysis to ammonia (NH3), which is a more powerful reducing agent than hydrocarbons.

NH3 is currently the preferred SCR reductant due to its unparalleled efficiency and selectivity, but its direct use is impractical because of concerns over storage and toxicity. Instead, modern NH3-SCR installations rely on the production of NH3 in situ from the decomposition of a suitable precursor. Aside from urea, ammonium formate was proposed and tested as an NH3 storage compound [11,12]. However, it was found to decompose partially into HCN under SCR-relevant conditions, especially at temperatures below 250 °C. It is important to note that HCN formation in this case is a side reaction that competes with NOx reduction rather than an inherent part of the reaction cycle.

Unlike ammonium formate, urea does not pose a risk of HCN formation upon decomposition. However, the produced NH3 can react with carbonyl compounds – most notably formaldehyde – which are commonly present in the exhaust gas of lean burn natural gas engines to form HCN. Zengel et al. [13] proposed that HCN formation on Fe-ZSM-5, Fe-BEA, Cu-SSZ-13 and V2O5/WO3-TiO2 passes through a formate route, which is similar to the previously proposed ammonium formate pathway [12]. In their mechanism, formaldehyde initially undergoes surface oxidation to formic acid and reacts with NH3 to form formamide, which then dehydrates to yield HCN. This was supported by the detection of adsorbed formate species and formamide on Fe-ZSM-5 by infrared spectroscopy. In another study, Ngo et al. [14] showed that the formamide intermediate decomposes between 250 and 400 °C by dehydration to form HCN, but can also undergo decarbonylation to a smaller extent to yield carbon monoxide (CO) and NH3. Above 400 °C, the formed HCN decomposes to carbon dioxide (CO2), nitric oxide (NO), and water. In our recent study on this topic [15], we have hypothesized that formaldehyde reacts with NH3 directly without intermediate formate species based on two observations. First, HCN production from formaldehyde increased steadily with temperature from 200 to 500 °C. Second, HCN production from formic acid reached a maximum at 250 °C and occurred only in the absence of water. The initial step of our proposed pathway [15] involves the reaction of formaldehyde and NH3 to form methanolamine, which can oxidatively dehydrate to formamide and then dehydrate to HCN. Alternatively, methanolamine can undergo dehydration to form methanimine, which then oxidizes to HCN.

In this study, we investigated the reaction of formaldehyde and formic acid with NH3 over V2O5/WO3-TiO2 and TiO2 by operando diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy. The experiments were conducted at 300 °C, a temperature at which HCN is a major product of the side reaction between formaldehyde and NH3 [15]. At this temperature, HCN can also be formed from formic acid, but only under dry conditions.

The 2 wt% V2O5/WO3-TiO2 sample was prepared by wet impregnation. A sufficient amount of ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3; Fluka, >99.0 %) was dissolved in water at 60 °C, and was mixed with 10 wt% WO3/TiO2 (DT-52, Cristal) for 1 h. After removal of water under reduced pressure, the sample was calcined at 550 °C for 10 h in a muffle furnace.
TiO2 (DT-51-D, Cristal) was calcined at 550 °C for 10 h in a muffle furnace without additional modification.
Both powders were sieved to obtain a particle size between 150 and 200 μm prior to use.

Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectra were collected using a Vertex70 spectrometer (Bruker) equipped with an MCT detector. Spectra were recorded from 4000 to 1000 cm−1 at a resolution of 4 cm−1 and scanner velocity of 80 kHz. The sample and background spectra resulted from averaging 10 and 50 scans, respectively.

Approximately 50 mg of each sample were loaded into the custom-built spectroscopic cell [16], which was equipped with a 2-mm-thick calcium fluoride window (Crystran) and was attached to a Praying Mantis™ diffuse reflection accessory (Harrick). Prior to every experiment, the sample was dehydrated under 5 vol% O2/Ar at 400 °C for 1 h.

For the operando experiments, various mixtures of 150 ppm formaldehyde or formic acid, 1000 ppm NH3, and 5 vol% O2 balanced in Ar were admitted to the cell. Where required, 2 vol% H2O was added to the feed. The total flow for all experiments was fixed at 100 mL min−1.
An Omnistar GSD 320 mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer) was connected at the outlet of the cell to monitor m/z = 17 (NH3), 18 (H2O), 27 (HCN), 29 (formaldehyde), and 32 (O2 or methanol).

Formaldehyde was generated in situ from the reaction of methanol and O2 in a pre-oxidation reactor containing the same V2O5/WO3-TiO2 catalyst (200–500 μm) as described previously [15]. For this purpose, Ar was bubbled through a 50 vol% aqueous solution of methanol at ambient temperature before mixing with air and flowing through the catalyst bed heated at 250 °C to produce 150 ppm formaldehyde. Under these conditions, methanol oxidation was not complete and the feed to the cell contained 10–15 ppm methanol as well as ∼1 ppm formic acid, ∼350 ppm carbon monoxide (CO), and ∼2000 ppm water.

Formic acid was dosed in the reactor by bubbling Ar through a 30 vol% aqueous solution of formic acid at ambient temperature and by-passing the pre-oxidation reactor. This resulted in 150 ppm formic acid in the feed.
Water was generated in situ from the reaction of H2 and O2 through a monolithic Pt/Al2O3 catalyst.

After background collection at 300 °C, the catalyst was equilibrated under formaldehyde (or formic acid)/O2 flow for 30 min followed by the addition of NH3 for 30 min. An identical experiment was performed by pre-equilibrating the catalyst under NH3/O2 for 30 min followed by the addition of formaldehyde for 30 min. To establish the stability of the adsorbed species, cut-off experiments were conducted by the sequential removal of formaldehyde and then NH3 from a formaldehyde/NH3/O2 feed each time after equilibration for 30 min.

Modulated excitation experiments were conducted by exposing the sample to alternating 60-s pulses of NH3 and formaldehyde/NH3 at 300 °C after equilibration under formaldehyde/NH3/O2 feed for 30 min. The time-resolved DRIFT spectra from at least ten modulation periods were converted into the corresponding phase-resolved spectra using the following equation [18,19]:
(1)

Fig. 1 shows the DRIFT spectra obtained during the adsorption of formaldehyde on V2O5/WO3-TiO2 at 300 °C in the presence of O2. Additionally, Table 1 lists the important IR signals that will be discussed in the succeeding subsections. In our previous work [15], we have shown that formaldehyde converts into CO and, to a lesser extent, CO2 under these experimental conditions. However, neither was observed in the spectra.

Two peaks at 2869 and 1701 cm−1 appeared as soon as formaldehyde entered the cell and correspond to the ν(C–H) and ν(C=O) modes of molecularly adsorbed formaldehyde, respectively [28,33]. The red-shift of ν(C=O) from the gas phase value of 1741 cm−1 suggests that formaldehyde coordinated specifically to Lewis acid sites [22]. Water, which was produced as a by-product of methanol oxidation in the pre-reactor or of formaldehyde oxidation in the spectroscopic cell, was also observed by virtue of the ν(O–H) mode at 1616 cm−1. Although residual methanol was detected at the outlet of the pre-oxidation reactor, no methoxy signal was observed, suggesting that the small amount of methanol that escaped oxidation before the DRIFT cell was oxidized upon contact with the catalyst at 300 °C.

Formaldehyde underwent chemical transformations rapidly, as the IR spectrum changed significantly between 5 and 10 s on stream. The peaks appearing at 1558 and 1363 cm−1 are associated with the asymmetric and symmetric ν(O–C–O) modes of bidentate formate species, respectively [33,34]. These bands are accompanied by the corresponding νas(O–C–O)+δ(C–H) and ν(C–H) modes at 2964 and 2869 cm−1, respectively [22]. Therefore, formaldehyde was oxidized under these conditions into surface formate species, which is in agreement with previous reports on TiO2-based catalysts. [35,36], The negative peaks at 2047 and 2014 cm−1 correspond to the first overtones of ν(V=O) and ν(W=O) modes of the surface termination of vanadyl and tungstenyl oxido-groups, respectively, reflecting the interaction of these sites with the adsorbates [21]. The negative signal at 3639 cm−1 is assigned to the stretch mode of hydroxyl groups, which were consumed by the interaction with formaldehyde and its products [37].

After 30 s, two new bands appeared at 2945 and 2840 cm−1 that are tentatively assigned to formate species with a different geometry (i.e., bridged formates). The corresponding νas(O–C–O) and νs(O–C–O) modes of the bridged species likely overlap with the existing signals of the bidentate species.

The weak signal at 1731 cm−1 suggests the presence of formaldehyde molecules that interact more weakly with the catalyst surface compared to those adsorbed on Lewis acid sites [38,39]. It is worth noting that the peaks corresponding to formaldehyde decreased in favor of the peaks belonging to formate species, suggesting the occurrence of the surface oxidation reaction. However, the persistence of the formaldehyde peaks at 1731 and 1701 cm−1 proves that the oxidation was only partial and that some adsorbed formaldehyde were still available to react. Continuation of the experiment up to 30 min resulted in the equilibration of all signals.

Fig. S-1 shows the spectrum obtained after NH3 adsorption on the catalyst. Two types of adsorbed NH3 can be detected: NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites (1602 and 1237 cm−1) and ammonium ions (NH4 +) coordinated to Brønsted-Lowry acid sites (1670 and 1432 cm−1) [21,26]. There does not appear to be a difference in the kinetics of adsorption of these two species as both appeared and evolved synchronously. If we assume a similar extinction coefficient for the two signals at 1602 and 1432 cm−1 [40], the large area of the latter suggests that the majority of adsorbed NH3 species is in the form of NH4 +. Indeed, the addition of WOx to the catalyst is recognized to impart Brønsted-Lowry acidity [41], at the expense of terminal Ti4+ Lewis acid sites [20]. NH3 adsorption produced the same negative signals at 2047 cm−1 (2ν(V=O)) and 2014 cm−1 (2ν(W=O)), in addition to 3686 and 3639 cm−1 due to coordination with Ti–OH and V–OH groups, respectively.

Fig. 2 a shows the spectrum obtained after formaldehyde adsorption followed by NH3 addition. For comparison, the spectra of formaldehyde-only and NH3-only adsorption are also given in Fig. 2c and b, respectively. The simultaneous presence of formaldehyde and NH3 on the catalyst surface produced chemical species that were reflected in a number of strong peaks at 1731, 1686, 1578, 1332 cm−1, and other signals that remain to be assigned conclusively. An almost identical spectrum was obtained for the opposite sequence (i.e., NH3 adsorption and then formaldehyde addition), suggesting that the result of the interaction on the catalyst surface was independent of the sequence of admittance of the two compounds (Fig. S-2).

The sharp and strong signal at 1731 cm−1 corresponds to the hydrogen-bonded formaldehyde molecules that appeared already in the absence of NH3 (Fig. 1) [27,38]. While we cannot discard the continued presence of the species responsible for the peak at 1701 cm−1 (i.e., Lewis-bound formaldehyde) under reaction conditions, the signal at 1731 cm−1 was remarkably more intense than it was in Fig. 1. The abundance of these weakly bonded formaldehyde species can be rationalized by the donor sites provided by NH3, with which the electronegative O atom of formaldehyde can form hydrogen bonds. Yu et al. [38] reported such signal in the overlayers of formaldehyde on TiO2(110).

The peak at 1686 cm−1 could originate from formate species, but the assignment can be disregarded because the signals in the high frequency region typical of the ν(C–H) and the νas(O–C–O)+δ(C–H) combination mode were missing. The signals at 1691 and 1685/1676 cm-1 were assigned to formamide under similar conditions in the IR spectra of Fe-ZSM-5 [13] and V2O5/WO3-TiO2 [14], respectively. Similarly, adsorption of formamide on other metal oxide surfaces provided a signal at ∼1690 cm−1 [42,43]. In order to assign this peak conclusively, formaldehyde was cut off from the feed after 30 min of reaction and the stability of the observed signals was evaluated. Fig. 3 a shows that the signal intensity of the carbonyl products was significantly decreased in the spectrum recorded 30 min after cut-off. The rapid extinction of the band at 1731 cm−1 upon the removal of gas-phase formaldehyde supports the assignment of this signal to formaldehyde. This implies that the adsorbed formaldehyde desorbed and/or reacted with NH3. Despite some intensity decrease, likely also caused by the simultaneous consumption of the signal at 1731 cm−1, the species associated with the signal at 1686 cm−1 persisted on the catalyst surface even after cutting NH3 off from the gas feed. Physical inspection of the sample revealed that the original yellowish catalyst powder exhibited white spots after the experiment, hinting at the formation of a polymeric residue. The continuous slow increase of the signals upon NH3 addition to the feed observed above supports this assignment. Hence, the species producing the signal at 1686 cm−1 was most likely a polyamide-like residue.

The experiment was repeated on TiO2 under otherwise identical conditions (Fig. 3b). The decrease in the intensity of the envelope centered at 1686 cm−1 was even smaller, and no other signal experienced the same significant attenuation as that of 1731 cm-1 in V2O5/WO3-TiO2. This behavior supports the absence of reactive carbonyl species on bare TiO2.

The peak at 2196 cm−1, which can be seen more clearly in the inset of Fig. 2, can be assigned to the ν(C≡N) mode of adsorbed cyanide species [23–25], which manifested only when both formaldehyde and NH3 were present. Fig. 4 shows the temporal evolution of this IR signal together with the MS data for HCN and formaldehyde upon the introduction of NH3. Adsorbed cyanide species increased even before HCN was detected in the gas phase, concomitant with the decrease of gas-phase formaldehyde. A smoothed version is given in Fig. S-3. Only when the surface cyanide species reached a certain level, did the level of HCN start to increase. This is the first time that the cyanide intermediate species was detected on the surface of the catalyst under a formaldehyde and NH3 gas mixture. Furthermore, this is a direct evidence that the side reaction occurs on the catalyst surface.

A modulated excitation experiment was performed to identify the source of the cyanide species as well as other species that can be catalytically relevant. This approach consisted of varying the concentration of formaldehyde in a gas feed containing NH3. After phase-sensitive detection (PSD, eq. 1), only the signals of the species responding to the formaldehyde pulses would be present in the spectra, thus enabling the disentanglement of complex spectral envelopes [26,44]. Fig. 5 a,b shows the time-resolved and phase-resolved spectra, respectively, of the formaldehyde pulsing experiment. The time-resolved spectra are characterized by the negative signals at 3649, 2047, and 2014 cm−1 and by the positive signals at 2196, 1731, 1686, and 1578 cm−1, which are already visible in the steady-state spectra presented in Fig. 2a. Besides baseline variations between 3400 and 2000 cm−1, likely as a result of the simultaneous addition of water together with formaldehyde, no other evident change is observed as a result of the pulses. On the contrary, the most prominent feature in the phase-resolved spectra is the sharp ν(C≡N) peak at 2196 cm−1 (Fig. 5b). This reveals that although cyanides could be a minor species because of their weak signal in the time-resolved spectra, their surface concentration was strongly affected by formaldehyde and its production was repeatedly switched on and off during the pulses. Moreover, this also confirms that most of the other signals appearing in the region are accumulation products because their response to the modulation was poor.

The peak assigned to the weakly bonded formaldehyde (1731 cm−1) was clearly visible in the phase-resolved spectra and varied out of phase with that of the cyanide species (2196 cm−1) – a clear indication of the transformation of the reactant into the adsorbed intermediate. In contrast, the signal from the amide product was not appreciably perturbed, indicating that its surface concentration was not sensitive to the variations in the gas-phase concentration of formaldehyde on the time scale of the pulses.

The phase-resolved spectra also revealed the presence of weaker signals at 1998 and 1976 cm−1, which are likely to be assigned to the perturbation of VOx and WOx groups [45], and of signals at 1832, 1813, 1796, 1549, 1503, 1461, 1378, 1315, and 1287 cm−1 (Fig. S-4) that are not discernable in the time-resolved data. Aside from the peak at 1731 cm−1, two other carbonyl signals appeared clearly in the phase-resolved data at 1765 and 1751 cm−1, which were asynchronous and delayed, suggesting a possible sequence of transformation of carbonyl groups. A clear signal appearing at 2893 cm−1 (ν(C–H)) varied synchronously to the envelope of signals around that at 1731 cm−1, and probably belongs to hydrogen-bonded formaldehyde. The peaks at 1501 and 1234 cm−1 could also belong to the same species [22]. The nature of some of the signals between 1900 and 1200 cm−1 leaves some room for discussion, but already suggests that the chemistry involved in the reaction of formaldehyde with NH3 is complex and that it could follow several paths. We cannot exclude that some of the unassigned signals can originate from the species present in the formaldehyde feed (e.g., methanol and formic acid) and only become visible because of the increased sensitivity after PSD. However, our time-resolved spectra are not significantly different from those reported by Ngo et al. [14].

Water was shown to inhibit HCN formation partly under SCR conditions [15]. Since 2000 ppm of water was produced upon formaldehyde generation, its effect was intrinsically present in all the spectra presented thus far. When water was deliberately added to the gas feed to reach 2 vol%, the ν(C≡N) signal vanished almost completely in the corresponding modulation experiment (Fig. 5c). A plausible explanation is that water destabilizes the C≡N groups through competitive adsorption and changes the product distribution to favor CO/CO2 [14,15].

To probe deeper into the kinetics of reactant consumption and product formation, the temporal behavior of the selected species upon single reactant cut-off was analyzed. Fig. 6 a shows that the formation of cyanide species followed a two-stage process. As soon as formaldehyde was introduced, ν(C≡N) increased abruptly and then levelled off after 20 s. In the subsequent formaldehyde cut-off, the signal dropped, indicating that the production of HCN stopped. However, the signal at 2196 cm−1 started to increase again after 80 s despite the absence of gas-phase formaldehyde in the feed. This implies that NH3 could still react with the adsorbed carbonyl compounds, although the major reaction was with the gas-phase reactant.

Formaldehyde and the amide product followed somewhat similar trends: both signals at 1731 and 1686 cm−1 increased in the presence of formaldehyde and decreased upon cut-off. The intensity of the signal assigned to the amide product varied less throughout the period, confirming the observation from the phase-resolved spectrum shown in Fig. 5b.

Adsorbed formaldehyde, on the other hand, did not accumulate immediately when gas-phase formaldehyde was introduced. In an alternative experiment where NH3 was absent, adsorbed formaldehyde reached a plateau almost immediately (Fig. 6a). This implies that HCN was preferentially formed in the presence of NH3 before formaldehyde could adsorb significantly on the surface. Thus, formaldehyde most likely reacts from the gas phase.

The complementary experiment where NH3 was cut off instead of formaldehyde is shown in Fig. 6b. Since formaldehyde was always present in the feed, the signal at 1731 cm−1 remained constant throughout the period. In contrast, both the amide and the surface cyanide species decreased when NH3 was removed, indicating that their formation required the presence of both formaldehyde and NH3.

The evolution of the ν(C≡N) signal in Fig. 6 followed different kinetics. In the case of formaldehyde addition to the feed, the adsorbed cyanide species reached its maximum signal promptly, just after 10 s. On the other hand, it took more than 40 s for the signal to reach a plateau in the case of NH3 addition. These data suggest that NH3 adsorption preceded the formation of cyanide species, which is expected due to the strong acid-base interaction between the catalyst and NH3. Although formaldehyde can coordinate strongly with the Lewis acid sites, this interaction is hampered by adsorbed NH3, as indicated by the shift of the major C=O peak from 1701 cm−1 (Fig. 1) to 1731 cm−1 (Fig. 2). Hence, the side reaction under investigation probably proceeds through an Eley-Rideal-type mechanism where formaldehyde reacts with pre-adsorbed NH3, which is analogous to the reaction of NO with adsorbed NH3 in the case of SCR and thus competes with the main reaction as indicated by the catalytic data [13–15].

These IR results confirm the existence of the amide pathway of HCN formation in our previously proposed mechanism [15]. However, we cannot exclude that the methanimine path also occurs in parallel. The difficulty of observing methanimine may be due to its transient behavior under reaction conditions (i.e., it is produced and consumed too quickly for detection) and/or absence of unique IR signatures.

Fig. 1 shows that formate species formed on the catalyst surface upon formaldehyde introduction. The relatively fast kinetics of this oxidative transformation limits the concentration of adsorbed molecular formaldehyde. Nonetheless, both formate species and adsorbed formaldehyde were present on the catalyst surface, and could potentially react with NH3 to form HCN. The ammonium formate route was proposed as a possible pathway for HCN production at low temperature (150 °C) [13,14]. We proposed that HCN does not originate from formate intermediates at 300 °C, especially in presence of water [15]. To determine whether formate species play a role in the side reaction at 300 °C, formic acid was admitted to the cell instead of formaldehyde. The resulting spectrum is presented in Fig. 7 a. For comparison, the spectra of the formic acid-only and NH3-only adsorption experiments are also shown in Fig. 7c and b, respectively. Under these conditions, formate species were also observed (1558 and 1363 cm−1) together with the signals of physisorbed water. While comparison of diffuse reflectance experiments is not straightforward, the much weaker intensity of the signal at 2961 cm−1 suggests that the overall less evident signals obtained with formic acid compared to the formaldehyde experiment (Fig. 1) are a result of the lower coverage of formate species obtained with formic acid.

The adsorbed formate species did interact with NH3, as evidenced by the appearance of new peaks at 1720 and 1672 cm−1 that can be assigned to carbonyl-containing species (Fig. 7a). However, the frequencies of these peaks were significantly different from those obtained with formaldehyde (Fig. 2a). These species are therefore of different nature. The peak at 1672 cm-1 could be assigned to the ν(C=O) of monodentate formate species [29,32], but it could also be attributed to an amide species. A change of adsorption geometry from bidentate (without NH3) to monodentate (with NH3) is difficult to justify but could be explained by the strong adsorption of NH3 on the acid sites, which likely limits the access to formate species and makes the monodentate geometry more favorable. However, the signal at 1672 cm−1 is very close to the signal at 1676 cm−1 that was assigned by Ngo et al. [14] to adsorbed formamide and this assignment appears more reasonable.

Furthermore, the peak at 1720 cm−1 could be assigned to the ν(C=O) mode of formic acid [29,30]. The same strong interaction of NH3 with the catalyst could prevent the adsorption of formic acid. In this scenario, a layer of adsorbed NH3 forms on the catalyst surface. With some of the active sites blocked, formic acid can then build up on top of the NH3 layer. Formic acid also appeared less reactive than formaldehyde: the typical signals of adsorbed NH3 above 3000 cm-1 were evident with formic acid but were absent in the spectrum obtained from formaldehyde and NH3 (Fig. 2a).

If we turn our attention to the inset of Fig. 7 and to the ν(C≡N) mode, it is clear that no signal was detected in the region between 2300 and 2100 cm−1. This signal is very weak compared to the broad background induced by the presence of water and NH3, but the contour plots of the experiments with formaldehyde (Figs. 8 a and S-6) and with formic acid (Figs. 8b and S-7) emphasize clearly the difference between the two experiments. The appearance of the peak at 2196 cm−1 with time on stream was visible only in the case of formaldehyde, suggesting that no cyanide intermediate was produced when formic acid reacted with NH3. Therefore, no cyanide species was formed when the signal at 1672 cm−1 was present.

While the amide products were formed in the presence of formaldehyde and of formic acid, the intense envelope of signals observed with formaldehyde in the region 1900−1200 cm−1 (Fig. 2) and the different position of the C=O signal of the amide product suggest that the reaction of formaldehyde with NH3 occurred via a more complex chemistry than the oxidation of formaldehyde to formic acid followed by reaction with NH3, and that it involved possibly other species. The subsequent reaction to produce cyanides and then HCN may be affected by the source of the amide product. The absence of adsorbed cyanide species in the case of formic acid (Fig. 7) suggests that formate species are not responsible for the HCN produced by the side reaction of formaldehyde and NH3 at 300 °C. Adsorbed amide species can also decompose to CO and NH3, but no gaseous CO signal was observed in the spectra [14].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Role of VOx, WOx, and TiO2
ce:section.ce:para: In previous modulation experiments where SCR was repeatedly turned on and off by pulsing NO in a gas feed containing NH3, VOx and WOx species exhibited significant contribution to the phase-resolved spectra [21]. During these pulses, NH3 bound to VOx was consumed intermittently by NO. WOx cannot activate NH3 to perform SCR under the experimental conditions but can serve as a reservoir to transfer adsorbed NH3 to the active sites. These active roles of VOx and WOx species in SCR caused their signals to be present in the phase-resolved spectra. In contrast, Fig. 5 shows that while the negative signals of VOx and WOx species were visible in the time-resolved spectra during formaldehyde pulsing, they provided only a very weak response in the phase-resolved spectra compared to the other signals. This is reinforced by the observation that the weak signal of cyanides in the time-resolved spectra was dominant in the phase-resolved spectra. Hence, the adsorbates accumulating on the catalyst justify the negative signals of VOx and WOx in the time-resolved spectra, but neither species is strictly essential for the reaction of formaldehyde and NH3, which explains their weak signals in the phase-resolved spectra.

To obtain more insights into this behavior, TiO2 was also investigated under the same experimental conditions. The resulting spectrum after the reaction on TiO2 is shown in Fig. 9 a. For comparison, the spectrum obtained in the case of V2O5/WO3-TiO2 is presented in Fig. 9b, which is identical to Fig. 2a. As indicated in Fig. 3b, similar adsorbed species were obtained on TiO2 upon flowing formaldehyde and NH3 at 300 °C. However, the removal of formaldehyde from the feed did not result in appreciable changes, hinting that the adsorbates are more stable on TiO2 than on V2O5/WO3-TiO2. The major carbonyl product produced by TiO2 was most probably an amide but as the corresponding peak was rather broad, the presence of other carbonyl compounds cannot be discarded. Other notable features present in Fig. 9a include formate species and the negative peak at 1378 cm−1, which originates from the interaction of sulfate groups present in the commercial TiO2 material with NH3 [46]. The characteristic hydroxyl groups of TiO2 at 3705, 3668, and 3633 cm−1 were consumed by the presence of the adsorbates. A signal centered at 2215 cm−1 also appeared, which can be assigned to cyanide species.

Fig. 10 displays the region that we attribute to cyanides in modulated excitation experiments with V2O5/WO3-TiO2 and TiO2. Fig. 10a shows that the signal at 2196 cm−1 of the cyanide species is the only detected peak in this region on V2O5/WO3-TiO2. This signal is represented positive because it is at a different phase angle compared to Fig. 5b. On the contrary, Fig. 10b demonstrates no evident signal for cyanides at 2196 cm−1 on TiO2. The change of baseline giving rise to the change in the color of the whole region is due to the presence of water entering the cell together with formaldehyde. On TiO2, the broad signal centered at 2215 cm−1 appeared in the presence of formaldehyde and red-shifted after removal of formaldehyde. Only phase sensitive analysis helped to identify the same signal at 2196 cm−1 observed for V2O5/WO3-TiO2. Fig. 10d shows the phase-resolved spectrum (ϕPSD = 130 °) where the signal at 2196 cm−1 was maximum and a second one (ϕPSD = 170 °) characterized by a weaker signal at 2215 cm−1. The difference in the phase angles suggests that the two signals followed different kinetics. The latter signal likely represents the fraction of species that contributes to the broad signal that shifts in the time-resolved spectra. Hence, the phase-resolved spectra reveal that cyanide species respond to the presence of formaldehyde on both catalysts but that on TiO2 other species are additionally present aside from the one that contributes to HCN formation. We tentatively assign this additional species and the signal at 2215 cm−1 to a pool of cyanides present on TiO2 that is absent on V2O5/WO3-TiO2 because of VOx and WOx. At this point, we cannot conclude on their role in HCN formation, but VOx and WOx species may contribute either to clean the surface from this species or to convert them efficiently into the active cyanide species at 2196 cm−1. The presence of this species on TiO2 could also be related to the lower reactivity of the signals below 1800 cm−1 compared to V2O5/WO3-TiO2 as shown in Fig. 3. The different behavior of TiO2 with respect to the adsorbed cyanides is also mirrored by the different response of the hydroxyl groups of the two materials that is visible in Fig. 9. While the hydroxyl groups of TiO2 were perturbed by the adsorbates, the even larger negative signal of hydroxyl groups at 3639 cm−1 in V2O5/WO3-TiO2 suggests the blockage of the TiO2 surface by VOx and WOx groups [20], thus diminishing the contribution of TiO2 to the observed chemistry. Therefore, VOx and WOx provide additional sitesthat activate the adsorbates differently. Hence, while the presence of VOx and WOx was not needed to produce cyanides, they nonetheless functioned to prevent formation of stable amide and cyanide species in favor of species that can be ultimately converted into HCN.

In this work, we used operando DRIFT spectroscopy to study the transformations that formaldehyde and NH3 undergo on V2O5/WO3-TiO2 and TiO2. Formaldehyde reacts from the gas phase with pre-adsorbed NH3 to form amide species and eventually HCN. For the first time, we reported the observation of adsorbed cyanide species that are related to the gas-phase product, and are strongly affected by the presence of the reactants. The adsorbed formate species are not responsible for the formation of the cyanide species under the investigated conditions. TiO2 alone is already active for the side reaction, but VOx and/or WOx sites promote the reaction by limiting the formation of unreactive amides and cyanides. Given the high toxicity of HCN, process considerations should involve the installation of an oxidation system either upstream of the SCR compartment to fully oxidize formaldehyde beforehand or downstream to decompose any potential HCN formed.

Rob Jeremiah G. Nuguid: Conceptualization, Investigation, Formal analysis, Writing - original draft, Writing - review & editing. Martin Elsener: Conceptualization, Writing - review & editing. Davide Ferri: Conceptualization, Validation, Supervision, Writing - review & editing. Oliver Kröcher: Supervision, Writing - review & editing.

ce:bib-reference.ce:source-text: Topsoe, N. Y.; Dumesic, J. A.; Topsoe, H., Vanadia-Titania Catalysts for Selective Catalytic Reduction of Nitric-Oxide by Ammonia: I.I. Studies of Active Sites and Formulation of Catalytic Cycles. J. Catal. 1995, 151 (1), 241-252.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Experimental microkinetic approach of De-NOx by NH3 on V2O5/WO3/TiO2 Catalysts. 2. Impact of superficial sulfate and/or VxOy groups on the heats of adsorption of adsorbed NH3 species
J. Phys. Chem. C
